title: Reese Witherspoon was 'nervous' meeting Jennifer Aniston on Friends
text:
She's been a fan favorite on film and television screens for decades.

But Reese Witherspoon earnestly remembered being 'really nervous' before meeting Jennifer Aniston on the set of Friends in 2000 as she sat down to chat with Harper's Bazaar.

Reese, 47, portrayed Jennifer's kid sister Jill Green on the popular program and was only 23-years-old when her budding friendship with the 50-year-old actress began.

Lady in red: Reese Witherspoon earnestly remembered being 'really nervous' before meeting Jennifer Aniston on the set of Friends in 2000 as she sat down to chat with Harper's Bazaar

'We met on the set of Friends; I played her sister,' Reese recalled. 'I was 23 years old and had just had a baby. I was nursing Ava on set, and Jen just kept going, "You have a baby?" I was like, "I know, it's weird."'

While Reese's character was only featured in two episodes, Jennifer was on hand to calm her nerves throughout the process.

'She was so sweet to me.' Witherspoon said. 'I was really nervous, and she was like, "Oh, my gosh — don’t worry about it!"'

'I marveled at her ability to perform in front of a live audience like that with no nerves,' Witherspoon said.

'They would change all the lines and she was just so effortlessly affable, bubbly, and sunny. We’ve been friends ever since.'

The powerful pair are joined together once again playing somewhat competitive journalists who face off on The Morning Show.

'Our characters are two people with very similar goals but different ideologies because of their backgrounds,' Reese said. 'Jen’s character existed in a world that was dominated by men. Just the fact that she existed was all that mattered.

'My character is like, "Hold on, no, no, no. If you’re not bringing other women with you, what are you doing?" It’s not antagonistic or competitive. It’s second-wave feminism meets fourth-wave feminism.'

They'll star alongside Steve Carell and Billy Crudup in the AppleTV+ program which premieres on Nov. 1.
